entry.title: Combined summary - A mining pool at 46%
entry.summary: Discussions surrounding the potential risk of a 51% attack on a mining pool that has reached 46% were raised in an email conversation. While some argued that launching such an attack would not be possible due to the decentralized nature of the pool, others pointed out that the pool owner has control over what goes into the block, which could potentially allow them to manipulate transactions. Additionally, there were concerns about the challenges faced by P2pool and the need to address vulnerabilities in the underlying technology. BTC Guild proposed a mitigation plan to prevent the network from being attacked by malicious entities. The plan includes raising PPS fees and PPLNS fees if its share exceeds 40%, and removing getwork based pools within 24 hours if its share goes up to 45% or more. However, Mike Hearn expressed his belief that p2pool had not been growing for a long time and had issues dealing with FPGA/ASIC hardware. Another member of the thread clarified that P2pool worked well with FPGAs and was being used by one of the largest FPGA farms.There were also discussions about the importance of understanding the kind of threat posed by a large amount of hash-power, as someone can replace confirmed blocks with an alternative chain that contains different transactions. Despite arguments about the difficulty of coordinating a 51% attack with random nonces, the possibility of a malicious actor creating one random number and incrementing from there cannot be completely dismissed. Melvin Carvalho brought up concerns about a mining pool reaching 46% and the possibility of a 51% attack. Discussions included the risks of double spending within blockchain technology, undoing vandalism to the chain, and manipulating the price downwards. While it was suggested that there are other mining protocols available that allow people to pool without the pool operator being able to pick which transactions go into the block, none of the pools listed on blockchain.info are meaningfully decentralized. The market will ultimately decide which algorithm is used, and as a community, they can review the different mining protocols and order them in terms of risk. Finally, there was a comment about supporting people who work on infrastructure and ensuring they have what they need to keep providing free services. It is important to address vulnerabilities in the underlying technology and ensure that infrastructure is secure to prevent potential attacks on the network.
